title: Robo-adviser Raiz hits $395 million in pocket change
text:
ASX-listed micro-investing app Raiz Invest grew funds under management by more than 50 per cent over the past 12 months to $394.6 million, as Millennials continue to warm to robo-advice.

Raiz, which was previously known as Acorns Grow Australia, allows users to access exchange-traded funds by "rounding up" retail purchases and investing the "spare change". The company grew its funds under management (FUM) by 13.6 per cent over the September quarter.

Raiz CEO George Lucas is launching the micro-investing app in Indonesia and Malaysia. James Alcock

Unlike most investment managers, however, Raiz's revenue is more dependant on customer numbers than the balance of funds held, given the average balance of its primarily younger customer base sits at just $1,666.

The smartphone application charges a flat fee of $2.50 a month – lifted from $1.25 per month in August – and generates revenue from non-customer sources such as third-party advertising, which grew 54 per cent year-on-year.

The fee hike did not result in a decline in the number of active paying customers, which reached 204,353 in the September quarter, up 5.1 per cent on the June quarter and 16.1 per cent year on year.
description: Micro-investing app Raiz Invest grew funds under management by more than 50 per cent over the past 12 months, as Millennials warm to robo-advice.
